content:
Hi, I created an email contact address book only on thunderbird. I changed PC in the meantime. How can I copy or transfer the contact address book from the old PC to the new PC? - Thank you, Gianfranco.

Export the address book on the old computer in LDIF format. Then import the LDIF file on the new computer.

content:
1. Cez webové rozhranie sa dostanete k údajom na svojom účte? 2. Problém môže byť aj vo vyššom zabezpečení na strane google.com.

Pokusne: - vypnite Thunderbird a "Správcovi úloh" preverte či v procesoch nebeží ešte nejaký Thunderbird. Ak áno, ukončite jeho proces - Cez webové rozhranie sa prihláste k svojmu účtu gmail a tu

  • vypnite dvojstupňové overenie
  • zapnite prístup pre menej bezpečné aplikácie
  • povoľte POP (alebo IMAP) prístup - podľa toho ktorý používate

- spustite Thunderbird a preverte funkčnosť,
creator: Ansamb

content:
Hello there We have read the question We try to help

Have you wiped your computer recently? Have you had any updates? Or have you changed the hard drive? were there any changes to your computer such as a different operating system?

If your profile folder is still intact, reinstalling Thunderbird will pick it up again and run it again when you reinstall your Thunderbird Software.


Greetings Firefox volunteer.
creator: Googlethunderbird

content:
Hello there

We expect symptoms from Thunderbird that you can no longer use your program or you open the inbox, it freezes or does not respond at all and inbox messages appear and then do not appear on the screen in this inbox. Or sometimes it is clear that the program is partially frozen and gives occasionally answers and sometimes not and behaves strangely.

The symptom could develop with an overcrowded inbox.


Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird

creator: @next

content:
The message counters in the status bar are gone. That's not a bug, it's been a deliberate change in TB115. Whether this has been a good idea is debatable.

The counter for selected messages now lives in the Message List Header. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova

Alternatively you may want to take a look at Betterbird. The message counters in the status bar have been restored there. https://betterbird.eu/
creator: christ1

content: Enable View/Layout/Message List Header to show the number selected.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thank you for the guidance.

Yes let me say emphatically that the new position for the message counters is a BAD IDEA. Now I have to waste vertical space to see the counter. What was wrong with its logical position in the status bar? The status bar has plenty of available space and is something most people will want to have showing, so why now move the counter to another bar that you have to enable? Where do I submit my vote saying it "ain't broke don't fix it" and mess it up - let's put the message counter back to where it was.
creator: eberger5

content:
By the way, one other issue. When I get a message in TBird saying someone responded to my post I can click "Mark is as solved" or "Doesn't solve my problem." If I click mark it solved, I would think it would take me to the support page to look at the message threads and perhaps add a comment. Instead it takes me to a blank white screen. It has worked that way for quite some time now.

The way to get back to the threads is to click "doesn't solve my problem." Is that the way it is meant to work?
creator: eberger5

content: You can voice your concerns at connect.mozilla.org and submit in the IDEAS section. I have posted several comments there. Whether anything happens, I don't know, but I felt better for having documented my issue.
creator: davidsk

content:
... let's put the message counter back to where it was.

For Thunderbird, this ship has sailed. If you want those counters in the status bar Betterbird is your best bet.
creator: christ1

content: Did realize Betteerbird existed. Very interesting. I think for now I will stay with TBird. Hopefully it will catch up. I like the Mozilla community.
creator: eberger5

content: The general direction is to move information out of the status bar to a location that is contextual/closest to the data - not just for message counts. This is a long desired change and unlikely to be reversed.
creator: wsmwk

content:
If you had to enter the address manually in the OAuth window, it's probably because cookies aren't accepted. Cookies must be accepted in TB Settings, at least for the MS authorization site, for the OAuth process to complete.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1417298#answer-1588949
creator: sfhowes

content: OK, I don't see cookies in the account settings. Is tb using firefox? Do I have to unrestrict cookies, but where?

content: I think you need to allow for login.microsoftonline.com also. A non-MS antivirus could also be blocking, or a VPN if applicable. Less likely, but not uncommon, is if you're running a server app. Run Windows in safe mode to bypass startup apps like these.

content:
If you have the same account on multiple devices, it's far simpler and more efficient to have them all IMAP instead of POP. But to switch from POP to IMAP, it's not sufficient to just change the server settings:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Convert_a_POP_account_to_a_IMAP_account

creator: steve.waechter

content: You wouldn't get that error with a regular consumer hotmail or outlook.com account, but you would with an Office365 domain account or Exchange account. Depending on the domain, IMAP and SMTP would have to be enabled by the admin, or in the case of Exchange, an add-on like Owl would be needed to access the account in TB.
